awd_titl_txt: Conference: NSF INCLUDES: Gathering to Create Culturally Relevant Biomimicry Pathways to STEM for Indigenous Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Indigenous students and Native ways of learning and knowing are vastly underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) fields. To address this challenge, we propose an in-person gathering to gain an understanding across disciplines and worldviews. The purpose of this proposed gathering is to further the INCLUDES Initiative goal of catalyzing the STEM enterprise to be more inclusive by exploring culturally relevant biomimicry pathways to encourage more Indigenous students into STEM fields. We see this gathering as phase one of a multi-year collaboration that builds synergies between biomimicry, Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK), and Indigenous communities. 

Low enrollment by Indigenous students in STEM is attributed to STEM’s exclusive roots in Western science with little acknowledgment of Indigenous ways of knowing, along with limited curricular linkages to their lived experiences. To address this low representation, we postulate that biomimicry, an emerging STEM discipline of emulating nature to create sustainable designs, could attract Indigenous students. Biomimicry recognizes multiple scientific roots, many shared with Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) of Indigenous peoples, of having a deep respect and relationship with nature. We propose a gathering where biomimicry acts as a bridge between Western and Indigenous knowledges, providing a pathway to broaden academic understanding of what constitutes valid science, thus engaging more Indigenous students in a wider array of STEM fields and becoming more inclusive and holistic. The gathering is based on an ethical framework of knowledge co-production built on reciprocity and relationality with an Indigenous-led planning committee and a focus on place-based knowledge of a desert ecosystem. Our aim is to expand solutions to environmental problems and healing ecosystems through two-eyed seeing –an approach of viewing the world through an Indigenous lens with one eye while the other eye sees through a Western lens, creating a more holistic and inclusive vision.

This project is funded by NSF’s Eddie Bernice Johnson Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (INCLUDES) Initiative, which seeks to motivate and accelerate collaborative infrastructure building to advance and sustain systemic change to broaden participation in STEM at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

The NSF INCLUDES project aimed to explore the integration of biomimicry and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) to engage Indigenous students in STEM research and careers. The project focused on establishing pathways that are culturally appropriate and inclusive, fostering collaboration between Indigenous and non-Indigenous stakeholders.

 

Project Key Objectives:

The project aimed to establish a diverse planning team tasked with developing a strategy for engaging Indigenous students in STEM through biomimicry and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) while concurrently creating a documented and culturally appropriate design process for the gathering. Additionally, the project sought to cultivate a network of Indigenous and non-Indigenous students, faculty, and practitioners eager to develop a biomimicry-informed path for attracting Indigenous students into STEM.

 

The project accomplished these objectives:

The project successfully achieved its objectives by establishing a diverse planning team of six individuals, including four Indigenous members representing various tribal affiliations. This team met regularly to conceptualize, plan, and execute the gathering. The event, hosted at Arizona State University and the Salt River Pima Maricopa Indian Community, drew 50 attendees, 75% identifying as Indigenous from 16 tribes spanning ages 17 to early 70s. Employing a "two-eyed seeing" framework, the gathering seamlessly integrated Indigenous and Western knowledge systems, utilizing biomimicry as a unifying bridge. Structured around four main panels led by team members, discussions delved into systemic barriers hindering STEM education and careers, the appropriate application of biomimicry with Indigenous peoples, and the alignment of biomimicry and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) to forge new pathways for Indigenous research and career opportunities in STEM. The insights from these discussions, captured through meticulous note-taking, flip charts, and graphic illustrations, furnish valuable data to guide future efforts in this vital domain.

 

Key Findings:

Biomimicry offers a culturally relevant pathway to engage Indigenous students in STEM, contingent upon addressing barriers to access and success. Central to this approach is prioritizing relationship-building with nature, integrating the Arts (STEAM) to enhance STEM inclusivity, and ensuring consultation with Indigenous communities to safeguard data and cultural sovereignty.

 

Outcomes:

The project yielded significant outcomes, including valuable training and professional development opportunities for student presenters. Furthermore, it successfully disseminated project findings through various channels, including academic publications and conference presentations. Additionally, the project established culturally relevant pathways for Indigenous students to access STEM, laying a foundation for future collaborations and initiatives in the field.

Intellectual Merit:

The project delved into an ethical framework for facilitating knowledge co-production between biomimicry and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), enriching the understanding and pedagogical approaches within STEM disciplines. It emphasized the core tenets of biomimicry, namely emulate, ethos, and reconnect, and juxtaposed them with Indigenous principles of relationality, reciprocity, and connection to place. This synthesis was exemplified through a field activity at the Salt River, guided by two community leaders and integrated with biomimicry pedagogy. The Indigenous-led planning committee also played a pivotal role in amplifying marginalized voices within STEM education, fostering an inclusive environment to address prevailing barriers.

Broader Impacts:

The project generated synergies between biomimicry and Indigenous knowledge systems, offering potential avenues to combat epistemic injustice, devise innovative solutions to environmental challenges, and foster ecosystem healing through the lens of "two-eyed seeing." Its meticulously designed format serves as a model for future INCLUDES conferences, promoting a participatory planning process that embraces Indigenous ways of knowing and enhances racial and cultural inclusivity. Moreover, the gathering outcomes established novel culturally relevant pathways for Indigenous students to engage with STEM. Moving forward, the project aims to nurture a cohort of students and community members, guiding them towards nature-based STEM approaches that intertwine biomimicry with a deep appreciation of their cultural heritage.

 

In conclusion, the NSF INCLUDES gathering has made progress in exploring the potential of biomimicry as a culturally relevant pathway for engaging Indigenous students in STEM. The project has laid the groundwork for future collaborations and initiatives that aim to increase the representation and success of Indigenous students in STEM fields while respecting and incorporating their traditional knowledge and ways of knowing.


 


 

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2024
Modified by: Sara El-Sayed

    Panelists presenting

    Melissa Nelson
